content.title: Acute Cholecystitis
content.summary: Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, most commonly from gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct (calculous cholecystitis). Clinical features include RUQ pain, fever, and positive Murphy sign. Ultrasound is the initial diagnostic study, with HIDA scan for equivocal cases. Treatment is cholecystectomy, ideally within 72 hours of presentation.
key_points: Presentation: RUQ pain, fever, nausea, positive Murphy sign
Ultrasound: gallstones, gallbladder wall thickening >3mm, pericholecystic fluid
HIDA scan: non-visualization of gallbladder confirms cystic duct obstruction
Acalculous cholecystitis: critically ill patients; high morbidity and mortality
content.statement: Acute cholecystitis presents with RUQ pain, fever, and Murphy sign, diagnosed by ultrasound showing gallstones and wall thickening, and treated definitively with early laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

explanation.intuition: A gallstone blocks the gallbladder outlet (cystic duct), causing bile to back up. The trapped bile irritates and inflames the gallbladder wall. Think of it like a blocked drain causing water to back up and damage the pipes. The sooner you remove the gallbladder (fix the clog permanently), the better the outcome.
explanation.key_insight: Timing matters: early cholecystectomy (<72 hours) has lower complication rates, shorter hospital stays, and similar mortality compared to delayed surgery. The old teaching of 'cool down then operate later' has been replaced by 'operate early' in most cases.
explanation.technical_details: Murphy sign: inspiratory arrest during deep palpation of the RUQ due to pain when the inflamed gallbladder descends to meet the examining hand. Sonographic Murphy sign (pain with transducer pressure over gallbladder) is more reliable than clinical Murphy sign.

definitions_glossary.calculous_cholecystitis: Cholecystitis caused by gallstone(s) obstructing the cystic duct
definitions_glossary.acalculous_cholecystitis: Cholecystitis without gallstones; occurs in critically ill patients
definitions_glossary.Murphy_sign: Inspiratory arrest during RUQ palpation due to pain
definitions_glossary.sonographic_Murphy_sign: Pain when transducer compresses gallbladder on ultrasound
definitions_glossary.HIDA_scan: Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan; non-visualization = cystic duct obstruction
definitions_glossary.pericholecystic_fluid: Fluid around gallbladder indicating inflammation/wall edema
definitions_glossary.laparoscopic: Minimally invasive approach through small incisions
definitions_glossary.cholecystostomy: Percutaneous gallbladder drainage for non-surgical candidates

pathophysiology.mechanism: Gallstone impaction in cystic duct → bile stasis → gallbladder wall inflammation

calculous.cause: Gallstone obstructing cystic duct (90-95% of cases)
calculous.sequence: Distension → venous congestion → arterial compromise → ischemia/necrosis

symptoms: Right upper quadrant pain (>6 hours, differentiating from biliary colic)
Pain radiating to right shoulder or back
physical_exam: Murphy sign (inspiratory arrest with RUQ palpation)

Tokyo_guidelines_2018.definite_diagnosis: One A sign + one B sign + C; suspected: A + B

ultrasound_first_line.advantages: Cheap, fast, no radiation, bedside available

HIDA_scan.finding: Non-visualization of gallbladder at 4 hours (even with morphine augmentation)
HIDA_scan.limitation: Takes several hours; patient must be fasting

CT_scan.not_first_line: Less sensitive than US for uncomplicated cholecystitis

laboratory: Mild transaminase and bilirubin elevation (if Mirizzi syndrome or choledocholithiasis)

differential_diagnosis: Biliary colic (pain <6 hours, no fever, no wall thickening)
Ascending cholangitis (Charcot triad: fever, jaundice, RUQ pain)

laparoscopic_cholecystectomy.timing: Ideally within 72 hours of symptom onset
laparoscopic_cholecystectomy.rationale: Early surgery has lower complication rates than delayed

open_cholecystectomy.indication: Conversion from laparoscopic if difficult anatomy, bleeding, or injury

percutaneous_cholecystostomy.indication: High surgical risk (critically ill, severe comorbidities)

severity_grading.grade_I_mild: No organ dysfunction; normal surgical candidate
severity_grading.grade_II_moderate: Elevated WBC, palpable mass, >72h duration, gangrenous/emphysematous/abscess
severity_grading.grade_III_severe: Organ dysfunction (cardiovascular, neurological, respiratory, renal, hepatic)

definition.@value: Acute inflammation of the gallbladder, most commonly from gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct, presenting with RUQ pain, fever, and Murphy sign

scopeNote.@value: Covers calculous and acalculous types, diagnosis by ultrasound/HIDA, and early cholecystectomy

learning_objectives: Recognize the clinical presentation of acute cholecystitis
Interpret ultrasound findings diagnostic of cholecystitis
Apply Tokyo guidelines for diagnosis and severity grading
Justify early cholecystectomy (<72 hours) as preferred treatment
clinical_pearls: Murphy sign = inspiratory arrest during RUQ palpation
Sonographic Murphy sign is more reliable than clinical exam
HIDA scan: gallbladder not visualized at 4h = cystic duct obstruction = cholecystitis
Early cholecystectomy (<72h) is preferred over delayed surgery
Acalculous cholecystitis = ICU patient with RUQ pain - high mortality, low threshold to treat
common_misconceptions: Wait for inflammation to cool down before surgery - early surgery is now preferred
Ultrasound always shows the diagnosis - HIDA scan needed if equivocal
Acalculous cholecystitis is benign - it has higher morbidity/mortality
